page.title: 04Charing church
page.content: Charing church is dedicated to St. Peter and St. Paul. It has two side chapels in the north and south transepts. In 1590 the church caught fire and was almost completely destroyed. The original roof has been replaced by another, the beams of which have been beautifully painted so that they look like they have been carved. The church has a lovely rood screen erected in 1921 as a memorial to those who died in World War 1. Set in the wall by the main altar is a special seat. This is where the Archbishop of Canterbury used to sit. Charing Church has this special seat because Charing is on the old route from London to Canterbury, and the Archbishop used to stay at his Palace, which is next door to the church, on his way to Canterbury The Palace is now almost a ruin.
